under development.build_overview:
Spider-Man Noir is a Marvel character who is usually a free agent. He employs a series of Powers that heighten his natural strength, balance, and reflexes, along with some trained Techniques that enhance his stealthiness and accuracy. He relies on webbing to immobilize enemies, runaway vehicles, falling debris, and many other environmental hazards. His webbing also allows him far greater mobility while remaining stealthy.

There are lots of ways you could build a Spider-Man character in Caped Crusaders, but this build will try to focus on the conventional role Spider-Man usually takes when on a team. Peter is a real powerhouse, but constantly holds back in physical combat with few exceptions. When working with other heroes, Spidey often relies on his webbing and agility to tailor the battlefield for his allies rather than fight a boss villain one on one like we see in his solo adventures. Spider-Man Noir tends to stick to the shadows on his solo andventures, but that isn't always an option on a team. Spider-Man Noir does not lean into the genius side of Peter as much, and so we'll stick to the Wisdom skills rather than the Intelligence skills. Insight, Perception, and so on, will help give us that gritty dark private eye kinda feel when not in combat.

This Spider-Man is not at the center of the stage, and that's exactly how we want it for this build.
under development.race_description: Can't go wrong with a good old human.  Spidey is genetically altered, but we'll represent that through Powercasting.  For now we'll just take Perception and Insight.  We'll boost Dex by 1 and Wis by 2; Int seems extremely appropriate for Spidey, but only from a thematic perspective.  Mechanically, this version of Spider-Man never really uses his Intelligence in combat, so we'll be leaving Spider-Man Noir as a regular joe in regards to raw IQ.
under development.background_description: Thematically appropriate; we'll also take advantage of the Skulker feat to increase our stealthiness.  This will help when sneaking out of combat and allow us to more easily get the drop on distracted enemies in combat.

level_guide.walkthrough:
At level one we will be focusing on slinging debuff cantrips, swooping in to Shove, and kiting back to safety. We have to be careful when swooping in though, since our movement hasn't been buffed all that much yet; we have to rely on our tankier teammates to draw fire away from us. If that isn't something that will work out more often than not, we'll just stick to casting from a distance.

We'll grab Distracting Blast to represent a little web attack that can help make our enemies easier to defeat. We'll also take Agility to help us escape sticky situations while avoiding Opportunity Attacks.

We also get a leveled Superpower, which we'll use sparingly if the situation calls for it. We'll keep Slowing Arc for medium hordes that could use a tripping before the Martials rip them up.

Here we get our Subclass, and we'll be going down the Neutralizer path. This will help us blend in some training to represent a gritty and more experienced Spider-Man Noir. We'll be taking the Take Aim Technique, which grants us increased precision on our Attacks rolls if we sacrifice some movement. Consider that we will be out of harm's way most of the time anyyways, this will help us be more effective at a safe distance. We've got the reaction movement to cover everything we should need most of the time anyways.

We also get another Consumable, so we'll be taking Stunning Shot for larger enemies that are hitting our allies (or us) a bit too hard.
We'll take the Keen Eye feat and round out our Wis score.
Second Level Superpowers!
There are a lot of things we could do here, but maxing out our casting stat is always a good option. ASI for +2 Wis.

under development.build_overview:
Cyborg is a DC character who was seriously injured and had to bond with alien technology in order to survive, which ended up replacing his missing body parts with advanced cybernetic components. He wields powerful technology and the knowledge of how to use it, but his cybernetic interface gives him a more tuned and innate control over his technological components than a standard Visionary might have.

We'll be focusing on boosting our defenses and making sure we've got a few good blasts to replicate his signature hand cannon, along with the standard options every Visionary ought to focus on. The boons we'll be taking amplify and enforce the concept of cybernetic bonding.

As we reach higher levels, we'll also focus on acquiring advanced vehicles with which we can shuttle the party around with.
under development.race_description: Thematically appropriate; +2 Int and +1 Con is exactly what we want.  We'll take Binary for our Language and Hacking for our Tool prof to make our Cyborg feel like a real living machine.
under development.background_description: Thematically appropriate; we'll also take advantage of the Longshot feat to increase the range of our Sonic Cannon.

level_guide.walkthrough:
At level one we will be focusing on slinging cantrips, keeping ourselves out of the fray, laying down some small AoEs to trip up smaller enemies, and buffing allies to face bigger enemies. Of course, the Visionary is also excellent at out of combat utility, so we'll be sure to be reliable in that regard.

We'll be grabbing Omnibeam, Interactive Tutorial, and Repulsing Blast for our cantrips. Interactive Tutorial gives a welcome boost on a large portion of skill checks, both for ourselves and others. The other two are decent damage options, but the real draw is the additional effects. Being able to add a bit of forced movement every turn or select a specific damage type if we know what threat will be coming tomorrow can make a big difference. We could deal a bit more damage from a safer distance with Focused Beam, but I'm a fan of cantrips that do something other than just damage; if we wanted to do raw damage, we could play a Dynamo or Annointed instead.

For our leveled Technologies, we'll be taking Reflective Insulators to boost our defenses, Taser Snare for some battlefield control, Impact Dampeners to avoid falling damage, and Chromabeam for exploiting enemy vulnerabilities. I know two of these might not get used (which is a good thing; it means we are positioning ourselves properly), but having them available really covers our ass. If we need them and don't have them, and odds are you will need them, you might not survive the fight. Don't worry though, we'll take more exciting options later on; our job right now is surviving long enough to see those higher levels.

Now we get our subclass, which grants us some Sustainables throughout our character's lifespan.  We will be going with the Magnate subclass and selecting Deflect Projectiles to give us some increased defense against ranged attacks (which is the only kind of attack we should ever be worried about if we are positioning ourselves properly).  Homing Darts is a nice way to force Concentration saves, and Imapct Dampeners further increases our survivability.

Second level Technologies!  This is why we play full casters.  We'll be grabbing Rocket Burst and Hologram Projector.  The extra speed from Rocket Burst can be great if there is a target that needs to be reached quickly (and we don't happen to have a Subvertist in the group), or if we find ourselves caught in a horde and want to get far away without risking opportunity attacks.  Hologram Projector is wildly useful.  It can be used for all kinds of deceptive tactics outside of combat, and can effectively block line of sight if placed correctly in combat.  If you aren't creative, no worries; making a hologram of a metal dome that imposes disadvantage on incoming ranged attacks while your party melees the mooks they can reach is still extremely useful.  Think of it like a limited terrain feature that you get to control.
We'll take the Viral feat and round out our Int score.
There are a lot of things we could do here, but maxing out our casting stat is always a good option.  ASI for +2 Int.

entries.build_overview:
The Amazing Spider-Man is the original Peter Parker from the first run of Spider-Man comics, and what I consider to be the default Spider-Man that is seen most often on Marvel teams. This is a Spider-Man who relies on webbing to do the heavy lifting and tailor the battlefield for his allies, while also making sure to keep a safe distance from nasty threats.

There are lots of ways you could build a Spider-Man character in Caped Crusaders, but this build will try to focus on the conventional role Spider-Man usually takes when on a team. Peter is a real powerhouse, but constantly holds back in physical combat with few exceptions. When working with other heroes, Spidey often relies on his webbing and agility to alter the terms of engagement rather than fight a boss villain one on one like we see in his solo adventures.

This Spider-Man build does not lean into the genius side of Peter as much since it is relevant to game mechanics in almost no way. Peter may be a genius, but it's not exactly something that comes up often in combat. Most of his abilities are based on his powers and senses. I know I know, he comes up with clever gizmos to defeat specific enemies, but he doesn't rely on raw Intelligence (or even develop it much; his academic performance is often in shambles for the majority of his life) for most of his abilities. We can be a more effective Spider-Man if we leave the genius side of Peter represented with appropriate skill and tool proficiencies, which do the job just fine in my estimation regardless.

In conclusion, we will be sticking to Wisdom for this build and opting for Int based skills. We will be taking lots of control casting options to represent the various applications for webbing, and we will do our best to stay out of the fray. This Spider-Man is not at the center of the stage, and that's exactly how we want it.

*Technical note, some of you may protest the use of Powercasting to represent Spidey's web based abilities since his webshooters are actually technological devices. In theory, we could try to build a Spider-Man that uses Techcasting to represent webbing, but Powercasting also represents Spider-Man's extreme feats of agility and strength. A build that does use Techcasting based webbing would be the Iron Spider, who also employs a variety of other gadgets. Webshooters alone aren't necessarily complex enough to be represented through Techcasting in my estimation. Peter's ability to use his webbing effectively relies more heavily on his natural reflexes and accuracy than on the technology of the webbing or webshooters themselves. If this perspective continues to bother you, then this build can also be used top represent Tobey Maguire's Spider-Man (whose webbing is organic and has no technological components whatsoever).
entries.race_description: Can't go wrong with a good old human.  Spidey is genetically altered, but we'll represent that through Powercasting.  For now we'll just take Perception and Science.  We'll boost Dex by 1 and Wis by 2; Int seems extremely appropriate for Spidey, but only from a thematic perspective.  As mentioned above, this version of Spider-Man never really uses his Intelligence score in combat, so we'll be leaving the Amazing Spider-Man as a regular joe in regards to raw IQ.
entries.background_description: Thematically appropriate; we'll also take advantage of the Academic feat to offset our less than thematic Intelligence score.

level_guide.walkthrough:
At level one we will be focusing on slinging debuff cantrips, swooping in to Shove, and kiting back to safety. We have to be careful when swooping in though, since our movement hasn't been buffed all that much yet; we have to rely on our tankier teammates to draw fire away from us. If that isn't something that will work out more often than not, we'll just stick to casting from a distance.

We'll grab Distracting Blast to represent a little web attack that can help make our enemies easier to defeat.

We also get a leveled Superpower, which we'll use sparingly if the situation calls for it. We'll keep Slowing Arc for medium hordes that could use a tripping before the Martials rip them up.

Here we get our Subclass, and we'll be going down the Enhancement path. This will help us increase our senses and durability to feel like a bit more of the hyper aware acrobat that Spidey is. We'll be taking the Reflex Dodge Enhancement, which lets us boost our AC against an incoming attack and skirt away to safety. This is a good baby step towards a full fledged Spider-Sense.

We also get another Consumable, so we'll be taking Stunning Shot for larger enemies that are hitting our allies (or us) a bit too hard.

We'll take the Keen Eye feat and round out our Wis score. Keen Eye allows us to sacrifice a bit of movement in order to make more accurate attacks, which shouldn't be much of a problem if we are positioning ourselves correctly. If we do manage to get targeted, Reflex Dodge should be able to keep us intact. The best part about increasing our attacks is the ability to synergize with our Distracting Shot cantrip. We can buff our own attack on one turn, making it more likely to impose the debuff, which then makes it easier to snag those enemies in an AoE on the turn after. Even if we have to sacrifice the first round by getting into position, this can make for a nice little combo during longer fights.

Our allies are getting a bit beefier, but so are our enemies. We can start being a bit more liberal with our leveled Superpowers as long as we keep some reserves for whatever boss might be anticipated.

Disorienting Surge is a nice addition that can help prevent the martials from being surrounded. Best for when the enemies are coming in waves or are forced into a bottleneck of some kind.

Second Level Superpowers!  We've been pretty good about using our webbing to trip up enemies, but we also need to make sure we can keep civilians safe from falling debris or themselves.  We'll take Vortex Flurry, which allows us to select a few targets within a decent range and negate their fall damage.  This can only be used in a few situations, but they tend to come up often enough and are very difficult to deal with if you don't have mechanics designed for it or built around it.

There are a lot of things we could do here, but maxing out our casting stat is always a good option. ASI for +2 Wis.

We'll also take a new Superpower that can force enemy movement, such as Repelling Burst. We'll be using this to launch enemies into dangerous places such as environmental hazards, clusters for other damage casters to blast on, or even into our own existing AoEs. This is a Superpower that ought to be upcast later on as well, but sadly won't get as much mileage out of Keen Eye as our other options.

The downside to this Superpower is that if we want to take a thinly dispersed crowd and condense them towards a central point, we'll have to move around the battlefield a fair amount throughout the casting. It's a worthwhile tradeoff when it's called for, and we can still use Keen Eye with this Superpower when in linear environments like hallways or valleys.

At level 6 we get a new Enhancement, which we will use to further develop our Spider-Sense and reflexes. We'll take Evasive to get a bit better at Dex saves and make it easier to get the drop on enemies in the heat of battle. We can couple this with Blinding Shot next level to quickly break line of sight and virtually disappear, making it that much easier to snag them with a debuff on the next turn.

We'll also grab Trip Assist for our new Superpower, which allows us to move an enemy in any direction and knock them prone. This is a nice way to represent Spidey's ability to yank enemies and throw them around with his webbing.

We get another cantrip, so we'll be taking Blinding Shot to help us break line of sight or improve our Shoving against bosses. It only lasts until our turn ends, so we can't coordinate with allies as much as we might like. Some exceptions such as Soldier Strategies might apply, but it's not what we are taking this option for.

We also get third level Superpowers, which is a big deal. We'll take Slingshot to help us punch a hole in groups of enemies or send them flying off of high ledges.

We will be taking Resilient Constitution for our feat this level. We've got enough casting options to keep a concentration Superopower active in most fights now, and keeping those up will free more Power Points for other things. Even though we have been building up our defenses in order to avoid or limit damage, this will make it that much harder to break our concentration when we do end up getting hit by something. Also, we'll be rounding out our Con score and getting an extra hit point for every class level. Spidey can take a beating, and now we are that much tougher.

We get another Superpower, so we'll grab Vortex Tunnel to make sure we can keep civilians out of harm's way should a runaway vehicle come barging through.

The Enhanced Movement improvement is a welcome addition. In many Caped Crusaders campaigns, there are a notable number of encounters with serious vertical terrain. Flying speeds are nice for this, but as long as the terrain has some relatively minimal features, our mobility is about as good as it gets across the game. A Subvertist built around Speed will outpace us, but they'll be limited to solid surfaces. We've got a very useful balance between raw speed and the ability to position ourselves almost any way we like.

Our last 3rd level Superpower will be Gravity Assist, which allows us to represent Spidey snagging something heavy with his webs and throwing it downwards at an enemy.

We are in the double digits now, which means we get our first 4th level Superpower. We'll be taking Lockdown to immobilize heavy objects, vehicles, or enemies. This effectively represents Spidey attaching a bunch of webs between the target and various anchor points. This can keep a malfunctioning helicopter from crashing onto a crowd, halting a runaway truck in its tracks, or securing a dangerous enemy in a cozy straight jacket while your buddies teach them some manners.

We've also got a pretty sizable movement speed now, coming in at an even 100 feet per round. This should give us more than enough mobility to get all our Shoves off, unleash a nice Superpower, and make it back to a safe vantage point.

entries.build_overview:
Legolas is an elven archer from the Lord of the Rings series who specializes in making a series of rapid lethal shots from a distance. Legolas can also grab some finesse blades and handle himself in melee, but we'll be focusing on his ranged abilities. We'll also be adding some nature based magic to expand our general combat toolbox.

There are a few ways to make a skilled warrior in Caped Crusaders, but only one fits our needs better than the rest. We'll be making Legolas a Marksman Ranger.

This build may not be the most accurate thing in existence given that I am not intimately familiar with Lord of the Rings, but my goal is to showcase the versatility of the Caped Crusaders system. The most glaring inaccuracy will likely be spell selections, so feel free to tweak this build as you like to suit your needs. If you happen to have feedback on how to improve this or other builds, feel free to join my discord using the link in the page footer and send me a message.

For this build, we'll be relying on Dexterity and a Longbow to deal our ranged damage. We'll also keep Wisdom relatively high for our spellcasting, but we will prioritize picks that don't care about our ability scores.
entries.race_description: Legolas is definitely an Elf, and going with Wood Elf nets us some useful weapon proficiencies should we find or craft a magic weapon later.  We'll take advantage of Perception by keeping our Wisdom respectable, and we'll greatly enjoy our Darkvision to get off Sneak Attacks.
entries.background_description: Thematically appropriate; we'll also take advantage of the Survivalist feat to make ourselves truly at home in the wilderness.

level_guide.walkthrough:
At level one we don't have much but our weapon and the Attack Action. We'll snag Extra Attack right away to make our tier one impact more significant, which stacks very nicely with Sneak Attack.

The general strategy is to avoid melee and make as many shots qualify for Sneak Attack as possible. If we can find a spot of Dim Light to dig ourselves into, then we should try to hold that position.

Here we get our Subclass, and we'll be going down the Spellcasting path. This will help expand our abilities while leaning into the fantasy theme.

We'll take Entangle to represent magical vines gripping and restraining enemies, slowing them down enough for us to pick them off before they can get to us.

We get another Technique, and we'll be taking Extra Attack again. This gets us three attacks per Action now, which is significant. We'll also learn Vigorous Leap for boosted mobility.

Our strategy is mostly unchanged, but we can afford to be more aggressive when selecting and defending our sniping position. While melee isn't our strong suit, we can pull out some swords and carve up enemies that get too close. This should be a backup strategy though.

Our first ASI, we'll be getting a Dex half feat to round out our main ability.  Lurker seems like a good choice, making us better at infiltrating.  We typically would avoid scouting solo in tier one, but we have enough Attacks and hit points to do so somewhat safely now.  I'd still recommend avoiding it unless the situation calls for it, and even then it needs to be handled cautiously.

Now we get our second baked in feature, and it's a useful one. Sharpshooter lets us slow down enemies and increase our accuracy at the cost of some damage. Unless we are facing enemies with AC in the very low teens, making sure our attacks hit will pay off more often than not. Getting more reliable Sneak Attacks and imposes movement penalties is well worth the damage modifier.

Create or Destroy Water is just handy to have for survival purposes since we might find ourselves in a desert at some point.

We get a new Technique, so we'll be taking Evasion to shore up our defense against saving throw based effects. The last thing we want is to get blindsided by a Fireball, and the levels when that is most likely are right upon us.

We can afford to group up with our allies a bit more now, but we should still avoid that unless there is some situational benefit for doing so.

We get 2nd level spells now, which isn't the most amazing thing for us, but it is helpful.  We'll take Spike Growth to give us another solid control option to reduce enemy speed.  This is best cast inside a big choke point against enemies without ranged attacks, allowing us to pick them off while they slowly and painfully make their way towards us.

We get another ASI, and we'll be maxing out our Dexterity to make us even better at what we already do best. This will boost our damage, accuracy, armor class, and some relevant skills.

At this point, we can afford to be very aggressive with our offensive strategy. We shouldn't be reckless, but we can definitely apply consistent damage to our enemies.

We get another Technique, and it's been a while since we got another Attack. We'll take Extra Attack again to increase our damage output.

We also get another spell, and we'll take Misty Step. This can get us out of a nasty situation should a big surly creature decide to get too close. Bonus Action teleport away to somewhere safer, avoid opportunity attacks, and make our ranged attacks as normal.

We are in the double digits now, which is where we'll be leaving this build off for now.  We get an improvement to our baked in Sneak Attack, which grants our allies an increase to their damage against a target we weaken.  This will scale again later on, but it's a nice way to offset the damage we are forgoing for increase accuracy through team coordination.

entries.build_overview:
Dr. Strange is a Marvel hero who uses powerful magic to create a wide variety of effects. Out of all the Avengers, he arguably has the most diverse pool of abilities to pull from. This can be difficult to represent mechancially, but lucky for me, 5e already has some solid mage classes and spell lists. Dr. Strange has few abilities that could not be represented using the 5e Wizard or Bard, but some of his powers are a bit more unique. The goal in combat is to serve as the ultimate handy man with the spell for the job. Being able to unleash battlefield control effects, defensive buffs, mass debuffs, mobility options, and direct damage effects are all important to options to at least have if not use for any self respecting mage.

There is really only one class to make a full casting mage with in Caped Crusaders, and that's the aptly named Archmage class. We'll be going down the Arcanoblate subclass in order to gain even more magical power through boons, and we'll be focusing on spells that can provide defense, mobility, and deal direct damage. We want to have access to our hand wards, portals, and the arcane whips that Strange employs so frequently.

We'll be sticking to Wisdom for this build in order to maximize our spellcasting potency, we'll focus on feats and boons that make us a more competent mage, and we'll be opting for combat spells with a few key utility selections included.
entries.race_description: Can't go wrong with a good old human.  Strange is capable of magic, but he's still a mortal man without it.  We'll boost Con by 1 and Wis by 2; Int seems somehwat appropriate for Strange, but only from a thematic perspective.  Strange is certainly smart, but his powers come from an awareness of reality and how to manipulate it that is best represented with Wisdom.  We will be snagging a feat to represent Strange's remarkable memory.
entries.background_description: Thematically appropriate; we'll also take advantage of the Academic feat to offset our less than thematic Intelligence score.

level_guide.walkthrough:
At level one we will be focusing on slinging our cantrips, the occassional damage spell, and staying alive with defensive spells. Our options are limited, but we've still got a wider variety than most classes. Our hit points are pitiful, so keeping at least a few spell points in reserve should we be targeted will be important if we want to see higher levels.

We'll be taking Firebolt for some reliable damage of a useful type that can also be used to ignite objects from a safe distance. Light is helpful for dark places when nothing flammable is around, and can be used to tag enemies that like to hide in shadows. Light tagging is very helpful when facing enemies that have sensistivity to bright light, or enemies that like to turn invisible.

We'll grab Feather Fall to prevent dying from fall damage. It's an embrassing way to go, and it doesn't take much to auto kill us at this level. Fog Cloud is an excellent way to provide some ranged cover, allowing us to effectively blind our enemy until we've closed the distance. Once they start stumbling out one at a time, picking them off becomes much easier. Bane is a nice debuff option that can be stacked onto a single opponent. While the effect won't stack, the saving throws will, allowing us to somewhat reliably inflict a penalty on larger enemies. There isn't much else we can do to shut down a boss creature other than Light tagging or speed reduction via Ray of Frost.

Here we get our Subclass, and we'll be going down the Boon path of the Arcanoblate. This will help us increase our overall magical potency. We'll be taking Primordial Levitation to represent Strange's cloak, and keep ourselves up and out of harm's way.

We also get more Spells, so we'll be taking Grease, Guiding Bolt, and Spectral Bindings to start fleshing out our versatile spell list. Grease allows us to trip up groups of smaller enemies, and is most effective inside a choke point. Keep in mind that we can create multiple effects since it isn't concentration, which can cover a prety large area. Guiding Bolt is a good option when we want to inflict some damage and set up an ally such as a Dynamo for a big hit. Spectral Bindings is a nice shutdown spell that we should save for bigger enemies that everyone can gang up on all at once.

Second level spells are here and they are a welcome addition.  We'll be using Silence to prevent enemies that rely on Sonic damage from blasting us too hard, and to prevent enemy casters from using Verbal components.  This is somewhat situational, but it's helpful when it applies.  Pass Wtihout Trace is a great stealth buff, allowing many parties to get the drop on enemies.  We should use this often and enjoy the benefits of surprising the enemy.  Heat Metal is a reliable way to disarm an enemy by heating their weapon, and offers recurring damage if we cast on an enemy's armor.  This isn't game changing, but being able to use this as a Bonus Action makes it more useful.

Here we get our first Ability Score Improvement. We'll be taking Observant to round out our Wisdom while boosting some useful skills of ours.

We'll also grab Mirror Image to boost our defenses, which can be combined with Dodging if we have something particularly important to keep concentrating on. Flaming Sphere is a nice AoE damage effect that we can position as needed on the battelfield. Misty Step is a helpful get out of jail free card, allowing us to teleport as a bonus action and avoid obstacles and opportunity attacks along the way.

Third level spells are here, and we are starting to feel our arcane power awaken. Ray of Frost is helpful if we are trying to keep a nasty melee creature from getting close to the party, and will almost always be my readied cantrip in an ambush.

We'll take Hypnotic Pattern to lock down a bunch of weaker enemies, and possibly some stronger ones too. You aren't as likely to snag the big guys with this effect, but there is no harm in including them in the area just to see what happens. Fireball is a classic spell that deals good damage, but should not be our default combat option. We should save this for clusters of enemies that we know don't have fire resistance or that can be killed with this casting. Slow is a helpful debuff for larger enemies that we want to ensure our effect applies to. By now, we've got some spell points to play with, so we can start being a bit more liberal in the application of our spells.

Another ASI, and we'll be putting both points into Wisdom to max it out.   We'll grab Daylight to deal with enemies that have sunlight sensitivity when light tagging isn't enough, which might not be all that often.  Somewhat campaign dependent.  We'll also take Spirit Guardians, giving us a solid self centered AoE to concentrate on.  We want to keep this spell up, so Dodging and even Mirror Image are perfectly fine uses of our Action after casting Spirit Guardians.  Counterspell is a nice option to shut down enemy spellcasting, but only when we know something nasty is coming our way.  We don't want to waste a 3rd level spell slot to negate a cantrip.

Fourth level spells, our magical power is really ramping up now.  We don't have as many options, but there are still some solid picks we can take.  Dimension Door is a powerful teleport option, allowing us to get in or out of a great many places.  Learning to rely on Dimension Door will enhance our mobility by a huge amount.  Greater Invisibility is something we will probably cast on an ally if they need to infiltrate, or to offer a nice combat buff.  It has some utility applications, but the versatility is the main reason we want it.  Banishment is a good save or suck spell that can leave an enemy boss dangling in between spaces while you clear out their minions.  You can also use this to send yourself back to your home plane should you ever find yourself wandering the cosmos without knowing up from down.

Our subclass is back to grant us another boon, so we'll be taking Planar Rebuke. This will let us impose some rather nasty effects on our enemies if they happen to be of some common varieties.

We'll take Wall of Fire for some battlefield control that deals damage, which can help thin the horde before they get to us. Secret Chest is a convenienent little spell that gives us a safe place to store our most precious equipment such as scrolls and spare spellbooks. Black Tentacles is a nice option when our enemies are constrained to a small area that make avoiding the effect difficult or impossible. Getting bludgeoned and restrained by other worldly tentacles is most detrimental when you can't simply walk around the portal.

Fifth level spells are here and we are becoming quite the arcane powerhouse. Mending is a handy cantrip to have, and can be used to make some neat mundane items if we have some prep time. Forging a pair of manacles that have no keyhole, breaking them, and then mending them onto a captive later is just one example.

Teleportation Cirlce is going to help us get around out of combat, especially if we have been jotting down the sigil sequences of places we've already visited. It does have a small cost, but it's probably negligible at this level. Antilife Shell can hedge out living things, allowing some encounters to be automatically won or even bypassed. Something like a horde of zombies is completely disarmed by this spell. Humongify is a cool buff that allows an ally (or yourself, but don't do that) to become really big. This extra size, attack, and damage, can help control the battlefield or direct the enemies' attention away from something more important.

Our last ASI for this build, so we'll end it off with Resilient Con to round out our Constitution and buff up our concentration saves.

Passwall will increase our ability to infiltrate, and we can make quick getaways if we want to trap an enemy somewhere. It being concentration allows us to drop it at will, so locking the door behind us is very plausible. Eruption is just a nice damage option, and it will do recurring damage unless the enemy wastes their action, both of which are good outcomes for us. Hold Creature can be powerful if they fail their saving throw, but it wouldn't be my go to. I'd save it for lone enemies that are powerful, and even then it will probably take a few tries to get the effect in place.
